body:
You're of course right. Can't remember reading that in the spec, but it's a while since I've looked at it.

I removed the check in my code and added a notice of Chrome not following the spec in the readme.

Thanks for letting me know :)
The [spec](http://dvcs.w3.org/hg/fullscreen/raw-file/tip/Overview.html) says nothing about how to handle keyboard input, so no wonder there are some inconsistencies.
Yeah but they're being overprotective IMO. Not sure what they expect developers to do with this API. Even games use alphanumeric keys. :shrug:
Never mind ! just seemed to be some memory overload on my computer ! It works fine on another pc !
I agree, didn't think of that. I've changed it now. Will fix it on my other repos with other changes. You should consider adding that recommendation to the EditorConfig site.

@sindresorhus Notifying users of this recommendation does seem like a good idea.

I'm not sure where we should put this advice on the website yet.  I just posted to the mailing list for advice.

Programmatic fullscreen mode is only single page. It's just Chrome that doesn't follow the spec.

See [Known inconsistencies](https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js#known-inconsistencies) in the readme.
But weird enough, this code http://pastebin.com/Jk5X5A4b works fine in Firefox, keeps fullscreen throught out requests, but not in chrome (version 19.0.1084.52).
Strange. It exits in Firefox when using this `document.documentElement.mozRequestFullScreen()` and navigating to another site.
maybe you already know that, but pressing F11, instead of using the api, fullscreen is maintained..
Yes, of course. But they have completely different usecases.
true story, understandable different behaviors.. it would be nice to be able to reproduce the F11, but i get the nasty things that could happen with ads and popus..
Ya, there is a reason it isn't spec'd like that.
Fixed. Thanks for the report :)
Fixed this an hour ago. Thanks anyway :)

You have to add the `allowfullscreen` attribute (+ attributes with vendor prefixes) to the iframe

https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js#request
Actually, just `|| fn.fullscreenElement` probably makes more sense.
Thanks for the report. Fixed in 1.0.2

Thanks man. I've modified the PR a little bit.

Can you confirm it works on Safari 5.1? And I'll tag a release.
Yes, it's working on 5.1 :+1:
IE doesn't support the Fullscreen API, not even IE10, maybe in IE20. That's why you check screenfull.enabled and have the ability to implement a fallback if it's not true.

Just tried it in IE10 and it returned `false`

![screenshot](https://www.evernote.com/shard/s1/sh/8d3a905d-aecf-4e3f-9212-a5aeaa7d4250/86c3b7fdbf3d075a219db18d74a1d0ff/res/16b294a9-77de-4544-a657-d49eeb781529/skitch.png)

Can you reproduce it on another machine?
I already had a list of supported browsers, but it's probably easier to let caniuse keep it up to date.
`.toggle()` calls `.request()`, so it shouldn't be any different.
touché, sorry about that.

That's not possible. From docs:

> Keep in mind that the browser will only enter fullscreen when initiated by user events like click, touch, key.
IE11 will support Fullscreen API with **ms** prefix. [reference](http://caniuse.com/#feat=fullscreen)
Tried the latest build out, but couldn't get fullscreen to trigger.
It's different and you can't. By design by the browser vendors.

onchange was a mistake.

You can already do that with `document.addEventListener(screenfull.raw.fullscreenchange, function () {});`

I should probably document that.
Aha, makes sense to use `screenfull.raw.fullscreenchange` as a enum.

Thanks so much :D Really appreciate you doing the work.

https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js/commit/928c2c9a6fb83dcd958b375830505fc10921ba8f
It seams it may have been a caching issue as it's operating correctly.
https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js#support

Using Browser: Chrome - Version 30.0.1599.69 m
JS - 
JQuery - v1.10.2
Bootstrap - v3.0.0
perfect-scrollbar - v0.4.5
Screenfull v1.1.0

Console throws error.. Not working.. Please help.

Works for me using Chrome Beta on a Nexus 4:

![2013-10-15 09 21 39](https://f.cloud.github.com/assets/9906/1332463/54721eda-357b-11e3-8caf-9e307d8a844e.png)

Scrolling works just fine, Chrome 31.

The fullscreen api is meant to be used on a single page. However there are ways to work around this by either making your page a single-page app or using this iframe trick https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js/blob/gh-pages/index.html#L202-L219

This is an issue tracker and not a support forum. Keep questions on StackOverflow ;)

Hi Thanks. But I don't get it the trick with the iframe. Sorry I am a noob in JS. I have lost of links/request inside my app and what I want to make fullscreen is my whole app. With the iframe trick I would need to make each button use the iframe? Is there a workaround? Thanks!

The idea is that you make another page that only has an iframe with your main site + screenfull.js. Then when you click links inside the iframe the browser will load the next page inside that frame, rather than taking the parent page out of fullscreen and navigating away.

Like sindresorhus said, this question really belongs on [StackOverflow](http://stackoverflow.com/). If you ask your question there I'd be happy to help you implement it further.

Hi. Thanks both for your helpful and quick answers. I opened a question here: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19440234/how-to-make-a-whole-website-run-under-fullscreen-with-screenfull-js

I would really appreciate if you can help me since I would love to have my app running in fullscreen mode in certain occasions.
Scroll is not working on windows 7 latest releases of modern browsers: Firefox 24 and chrome 30.0.1599.101m.

Hi Dan Pastusek. Is there any chance that you help me implement this solution? 
I have this opened question: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/19440234/how-to-make-a-whole-website-run-under-fullscreen-with-screenfull-js

Thanks a lot in advance!!!
Unfortunately that wouldn't work as it can be only be brought into fullscreen by a real user even on an element on the page (bookmarklet button doesn't count).
I also don't see the point. Browsers have built-in functionality in its GUI for toggling fullscreen.

For example, Firefox on OS X has problems after Lion:
https://support.mozilla.org/en-US/questions/932384

It doesn't actually fullscreen.  I would argue that this is a bug, but it isn't being fixed.  So I need a workaround.
http://chrome.google.com
No thanks. You can easily use the RJS shim config.
No no need to Since it is just a typo in the authors code you fixed yourself.
`MSFullscreenerror` too then I assume?
Yes, absolutely. I did not check this because I was not dealing with this event right now :)
Thanks :)

Hi Sindre,

The change in screenfull.js which I proposed wasn't communicated correctly
to you by Stuart Homfrey:

Please take a look here:

MemberType Description
_msRequestFullscreen_http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/dn254939%28v=vs.85%29.aspx
MethodRequests full-screen display of an image, video, or other element.
_msExitFullscreen_http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/dn254936%28v=vs.85%29.aspx
MethodReturns an element to its original size from full-screen mode.
_msFullscreenElement_http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/dn254937%28v=vs.85%29.aspx
PropertyReturns the top or current element that's being displayed in
full-screen mode. Otherwise it returns undefined.
_msFullscreenEnabled_http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/dn254938%28v=vs.85%29.aspx
PropertyReturns true if a document lets elements be displayed in
full-screen mode. Otherwise it returns false.
_MSFullscreenChange_http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/dn312066%28v=vs.85%29.aspx
EventFires when an element is displayed in full-screen mode, or when it
exits full-screen mode.
_MSFullscreenError_http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/dn312067%28v=vs.85%29.aspx
EventFires when a full-screen display is requested of an element, but this
request can't be fulfilled.
:_-ms-fullscreen_http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/dn312073%28v=vs.85%29.aspx
Pseudo
classEnables you to set specific CSS properties based on whether an element
is in full-screen mode or not.
::_-ms-backdrop_http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/dn312072%28v=vs.85%29.aspx
Pseudo
elementEnables you to set the background properties when an element is
displayed in full-screen mode.
_allowfullscreen_http://msdn.microsoft.com/en-us/library/ie/dn312070%28v=vs.85%29.aspx
AttributeEnables an iframe's content to display in full-screen mode. If
missing, only the iframe (and not the content within the frame) can go to
full-screen mode.
It must be MSFullscreenChange and MSFullScreenError. THis inconsistency of
using upper and lower cases is annoying. So far I know as a JavaScript
idiot JavaScript is here case sensitive.
I am also not experienced with GIT (I am using Mercurial for my PHP code)
so I didn't want to mess with the repository and correct the error by
myself. Sorry for that.

Beside that thank you very much for your full-screen wrapper - it is
working very well in all major browsers. Your script is a great help for me.

Best Regards,
Harald

https://github.com/sindresorhus/negative-array/issues/2
You don't need screenfull for the video element API, just use it directly. I'm not going to complicate the code for an outdated edge case like this.
I don't know, but I would ask on StackOverflow as this is more a general question about the JS Fullscreen API.

it's a shame that native fullscreen is different... Not allow really integration. This only its a fake integration because you press F11 its imposible trigger events... and disable o enable things... stupid things...

> Keep in mind that the browser will only enter fullscreen when initiated by user events like click, touch, key.

This is a security measure in the browser itself. Nothing can be done about it.
Sorry, i missed, thanks
lgtm. thanks!
Questions => StackOverflow
:cactus: :cake:
_slaps_ @sindresorhus
Thanks :)
Definitely not an issue with screenfull.js as it's just a sugar upon the native API. Sounds like a Chrome bug.
Why? It doesn't work server-side anyways.
True, but React allows you to render server & clientside with the same code, and this would prevent errors when including fullscreen.js in that environment.
Browser libs assumes a browser environment. Just exclude this lib and any others you don't need there.
Thanks, but I don't want to disable zooming.
Okay ;)
no thanks
Is RequireJS something you have no interest in supporting?

> RequireJS something you have no interest in supporting?

yes
No, but feel free to do it if you want to ;)
That's how the fullscreen API works in Chrome. This lib doesn't implement the actual fullscreening, but rather wraps it in a nicer and cross-browser API.
iOS doesn't support the Fullscreen API.

This is just an example with bad code, but works fine on iPad:
http://jsfiddle.net/4veeH/

iPhone doesn't matter since it always plays in the native player.
It just seems weird to load a framework to make cross-browser fullscreen easier and also have to implement another solution just for 1 browser
Already mentioned in the readme: https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js#support ;)

there you say this:
Safari 5.1 doesn't support use of the keyboard in fullscreen.

i have version 7.1, it's the same?
fixed https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js/commit/1ad2c970569da1b0317cb74bdb41d683b6b1993d
Not really. Only way I can think of is browser-sniffing and not super interested in adding that.
Yes, I fully understand this. Thanks for your fast response.

Not that I'm aware of. At least in Chrome the "native" fullscreen is also different from the programmatic fullscreen, where the former shows the tabs. So you would still want to enter the programmatic fullscreen even if the user is already in the former one.
This module is just a wrapper around the native APIs. Any behaviour bug is a bug in the browser itself.
For CommonJS it's using `module.exports`, not window: https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js/blob/46c1db251b1fece41a7097eece969a74100788b1/src/screenfull.js#L145-L146

I think we didn't understand each other. Sorry about that, I'll try to explain one more time.

There is some module, let `a.js`. Inside the module we have a such line of code: `var screenfull = require('screenfull');`.

When I use `a` module in a browser — everything is ok: screenfull works. Now I try to use it in nodejs (certainly, I don't need to use screenfull, but it should be parsed without errors such as it's required inside `a`).

When I try to require the a module I see such errors:

```
document is not defined
```

or

```
window is not defined
```

It occurs 'cause of inside `screenfull` it should be `global.document`, not just `document`.

Is it clear now?
iOS8 doesn't support the fullscreen API: http://caniuse.com/#feat=fullscreen

Pretty much here.

A feature. Bower packages shouldn't contain minified files.

Nothing new in this release other than removal of a couple of deprecated methods though. So just don't upgrade.
https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js/issues/66
Oops, thanks for letting me know. Done ;)
PS: new version will be on it in less then 15 mins.

Sounds like a bug with Chrome. This plugin just wraps the native APIs so not much I can do about it.

Make sure you're fullscreening the document though, and not an element. You could also try setting the body/html width/height to 100%.

Might also want to open a Chrome bug ticket (though make sure to include a reproducible test case):
https://code.google.com/p/chromium/issues/list
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/ask
That's intentional. You absolutely shouldn't directly link that. GitHub has hotlink limits. Rather use the referenced CDN link if you want to directly link to the script ;)
No thanks
What is it that doesn't work? Make sure you've read the documentation https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js#documentation.
Use StackOverflow for support questions: http://stackoverflow.com/questions/ask

Pretty good arguments against you (lol) as to why include minified version:

Claiming that minifying 3rd party artifacts is user's responsibility is not only odd, but would collide with so many corporate practices it's scares me to even write about. You are not supposed to do that. The sheer blame-war if something goes south... –  ZenMaster Oct 10 '13 at 16:16 

@SindreSorhus From the Angular Team, Best Practices. They specifically recommend using their minified file because they tweaked the settings just right. –  Jacob Eggers Jan 28 '14 at 1:59

## 

My only request is to not ignore your minified version on your bower.json. Not everyone is familiar with JS, gulp, grunt, uglify, yeoman, etc. Especially if the people come from a Java background and the only build tool for the project is Maven. If we want to setup a simple web project, adding build annotations and whatnot will confuse non familiarized developers of the steps they need to take to run the project locally on their computer. I would say that if three issues have been raised trying to achieve the same thing, it's a clear indicative of the need and usefulness of a minified version of your awesome library.
I agree, PR welcome ;)
I really hope nobody does. No reason to uselessly wrap it in jQuery.
Tape or Mocha.
There's no deal with uselessly wrapping this into a jQuery plugin. Also the code you submitted wouldn't even work.

jQuery seems to have no longer a bright future. jQuery was important to allow developers to create JavaScript code without the necessity to care about browser differences of the JavaSript implementation. But modern browsers are getting more and more homogeneous reg. JavaScript (ECMA 5.1 made this happen and the upcoming version 6 might cause difficulties for additional layers like jQuery to utilize all language features. So it is time to dig deeper into native JavaScript soon). 
For many scenarios vanilla JS (in its modern forms) is perfectly fine:
http://toddmotto.com/is-it-time-to-drop-jquery-essentials-to-learning-javascript-from-a-jquery-background/
If you need bulky stuff then the future will more likely move towards JS frameworks (like AngularJS):
https://www.airpair.com/angularjs/posts/jquery-angularjs-comparison-migration-walkthrough
So there is zero need for a jQuery plugin of screenfull.js.
-1, overwriting native methods is bad practice
That's how the native API works. This is just a small wrapper. Nothing I can do anything about.
Thanks, I thought it was the way your wrapper worked.

The fullscreen on the iPad is completely different from what's used here. Once upon a time Apple invented their own way to do fullscreening for videos, and only videos. That's what the iPad uses. I'm not adding support for it as it's legacy, properitary and only supports fullscreening videos.
PR updated

Do we really want examples of how to use it with a specific framework? I feel like how to use easy libraries in combination with a specific framework isn't something the library should document - rather something the framework's community should be aware of. 

I feel like if we start doing this we can add examples for every JavaScript framework out there...
I would usually agree, but Angular is super popular, so why not. If we get many more I'll just move them to links at the bottom instead.

From the readme:

> Safari doesn't support use of the keyboard in fullscreen.

Sorry.

Thanks!
This module is made for the browser. If you want to do server-side rendering with browser libs it's your responsibility to shim document/window, not the responsibility of every single lib you use.
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/ask
See this: http://caniuse.com/#feat=fullscreen -> Issues -> Issue 4. Seems to be an IE11 'feature'.
You need to listen to the [`fullscreenchange` event](https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js#raw). Your issue is just JS, though. Nothing specifically to do with this module.
Thanks!
You're right, added PR for this.
That is intentional. See closed issues.
Duplicate of #66
Although I did the PR, I think this is a good thing! Is it a general guideline by `bower` or is this your vision?

"Bower packages shouldn't contain minified files."
Interesting.. where is it documented? 9 of 10 bower packages has the minified script, like jQuery and Bootstrap.
I guess the idea behind it is to use `gulp`, `grunt` or maybe something else to package your app/website/whatever and to let them minify it for you.

Sure, I'm already using Grunt for merge and minify my custom scripts, but my vendors.js is just a merge from many bower packages and its .min.js files, I don't re-uglify them, because each has the minified file. Except this screenfull.js :) That's why I thought minified files should be included. Who/where says that it shouldn't? Can't find...

Not sure if it is documented... I'm not the one who made the statement ;).

I actually always use the unminified version and uglify/minify all the libraries myself into one big `libraries.min.js` file.
Both. I wrote that Bower guideline.
Hahaha, nice! :)

No thanks.

https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js/releases/tag/v3.0.0
Thanks :)
No thanks
I appreciate the PR, but this module is feature complete, so not interested in adding those properties. You can access them at `screenfull.raw.fullscreenchange` and `screenfull.raw.fullscreenerror`.

I totally missed that tiny line of code, sorry about that. Having said that, I don't exactly understand your rationale behind not exposing those two events in a more convenient way like all other functionality though. Its seems a bit off to me that one would need to use raw values (and full names) for the events but have convenience methods (with shorter names) for the rest. Could you explain this choice?
not working with angular2
@leocaseiro thx for help. actually I declared ToggleFullscreenDirective in wrong module that's why I was getting nothing. ':)
done!
The methods also needs to be documented in the readme.
Alright, I update reamde. But I think my method description is boring,  maybe you should edit it.
Thanks, but I don't want to add more bloat to the readme. It already documents way more than I would have liked.
We already define `document` at the top of the file, so I don't really see what this is fixing.

In the case of Ember.js server-side rendering (ember fastboot), `window` is defined but `window.document` is not. How about this line instead?

```js
var document = typeof window.document !== 'undefined' ? window.document : {};
```
Sure
Wouldn't you need to check `window` too?

this fix broke server environments
/frontend/node_modules/screenfull/dist/screenfull.js:9
	var document = window && typeof window.document !== 'undefined' ? window.document : {};
	               ^

ReferenceError: window is not defined
    at /frontend/node_modules/screenfull/dist/screenfull.js:9:17
Same here :(
@oskarrough yes when changing that it works much better. So it works for me.

> Additionally, I wanted to cache the regexp and even the result of the .test(), but that's something for a different PR.

👎 That seems like a premature optimization. It's not called very often.
Great. Thank you :)
Fair enough. :-) Thanks!
Thanks, but this is not meant to be an Angular guide. One example is enough. Angular users should be able to do the rest from that example and their experience.
The sentence *was* true when Screenfull was released, but it seems Apple has fixed that limitation in later Safari releases.
In Chrome 68, `document.body.webkitRequestFullScreen(Element.ALLOW_KEYBOARD_INPUT)` works fine, so I'm not sure what the issue actually is?

I would rather make them into Promises and do a new major version. It seems the use of promises are planned for the native implementation at some point too: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/Element/requestFullScreen#Return_value
Yep, sounds reasonable. Do you want me to adapt this PR?
Yes, that would be great. Probably smart to continue using the ES5 syntax, but note in the readme that people need a Promise polyfill for older browsers.
I think `toggle` should also return a promise.
Got you, will update it today or tomorrow

**Updated**
- `request` and `exit` now return Promises
- `toggle` returns result of `request` or `exit` and therefore also returns a Promise
- Dropped a note about IE support in readme

I tried demo page on chrome 68 and found this error. It is reproducible on multiple system, I can see it is working on some other chrome 68 as well. Not sure what 's the special settings that you need to turn on your chrome to reproduce this. Assume you cannot reproduce this but below line is still buggy: elem[request](keyboardAllowed && Element.ALLOW_KEYBOARD_INPUT); Let say keyboardAllowed is false so this method would be invoked with: elem[request](false) i.r webkitRequestFullScreen(false) But this method takes object as an argument and it will throw error as specified in screen shot. This PR will handle this case.
I cannot reproduce this on either 68.0.3440.106 or 70.0.3534.0 on macOS. Which exact Chrome version are you on? It might have been fixed in a minor v68 version.
I am on 68.0.3440.106

I confirm : Needed !
The built code should not be included. The code is built on new versions only.

This is standard browser behavior and is supposed to happen. From MDN:

> Navigating to another page, changing tabs, or switching to another application using any application switcher (or Alt-Tab) will likewise exit full-screen mode.

But IE and older version of chrome are working as expected..link opens in a new window/tab based on browser settings without exiting full-screen.

I am not seeing any errors in console in chrome.

Try it for yourself just using a standard `requestFullscreen()` JavaScript call. There's nothing in the screenfull code that specifically prevents this, which implies it's a change in the way Chrome works and outside your control I'd suspect.
Even if I try to view source by right clicking, will exit full screen mode.
Anything that removes focus from the full screen element is going to do that.

Try https://github.com/hrajchert/angular-screenfull instead.

For additional support, try Angular support forums instead.

@sindresorhus if we have a long page and after toggling to full screen there is no way to scroll down!
can this be resolved!

https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js#support

It's up to your to provide a promise polyfill. I'm not interested in bundling that.

I am using windows 10 and Chrome version 71.0.3
Scroll is not working in the demo.
Could this pull-request be accepted? Would love to pull in this version with npm in my project so it works again on the latest chrome :D fixing it in the dist isn't really an option over here :p
For a temporary fix, you could use [Patch-package](https://www.npmjs.com/package/patch-package) to patch the needed fixes at install time

> Even if I try to view source by right clicking, will exit full screen mode.

That isn't happening to me.

Ok, I feel stupid now. The problem was obvious.

With each ```() => someMethod()``` I'm creating a brand new function, with a completely different reference, so ```removeEventHandler``` is not able to find the reference and is not removing anything.
Closing as I don't foresee this PR being good enough to be merged. I'll fix this in master.
This package package is just a compatibility wrapper for the native fullscreen API. If scrolling is not working, it's either the native fullscreen API that is at fault or you using it incorrectly.
Thank you for your response. I'm not even using it. I just checked the demo and I opened this as this is happening in the demo.

So I figured out, that it happens, when I switch the tab or press ESC...

Then I get this error from Chrome:

`Failed to execute 'requestFullscreen' on 'Element': API can only be initiated by a user gesture.`

Issue resolved!

The problem was inside my programming. I called the fullscreen request after some seconds again and a again, which is no problem if one remains in fullscreen. 

But if you change the tab or exit the fullscreen, then in Chrome its not allowed to go into fullscreen without user interaction.

> so if you want me to follow this path, we will have to wait for a new release of tsd-check.

👍 Sounds like the best solution. I can wait for that PR.

> I've opened a PR with a fix, so if you want me to follow this path, we will have to wait for a new release of tsd-check.

This is fixed now.
The demo here is working fine in Chrome 73: https://sindresorhus.com/screenfull.js/ Make sure you're on the latest version and that you're using Screenfull correctly.

Shoule be throw error.

```
error TS2339: Property 'isFullscreen' does not exist on type 'typeof import("/home/travis/build/ng-alain/delon/integration/integration/node_modules/screenfull/dist/screenfull")'.
```

The TypeScript definition is correct according to the code:

https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js/blob/1bd0f448a5816c22a49b036bbd415af3b137fc7d/src/screenfull.js#L146-L154

If the fullscreen API is not supported at all, it will be `false`. The reason it's always documented as `if (screenfull.enabled) {` and not `if (screenfull && screenfull.enabled) {` is that `false.enabled` actually works in JS and is `undefined`.

> import * as screenfull from "screenfull";

You should import it as `import screenfull from 'screenfull';`.
The example in https://sindresorhus.com/screenfull.js/ works fine for me in Firefox 66. How are you using Screenfull? Also make sure you're on the latest version.
This is just a wrapper for the native Fullscreen API. Issues like these are issues in the browser and should be reported on the Safari issue tracker.

Duplicate of #126

I encountered the similar problem. In my case the change event is not fired both on the latest chrome and safari.

I found out this line https://github.com/sindresorhus/screenfull.js/blob/35c1a9eb34fd1c1a652b01e82b8d9a8357a679a6/src/screenfull.js#L64 is no longer effective.

That logic assumes if document has exitFullscreen property, it implements the standard API.

I tested if that logic still applies to the latest chrome, and it turns out the webkit implemented exitFullScreen, but the 'fullscreenchange' event has not been introduced yet.

It would be great if I could submit a pr for this matter. I am trying to figure out the cleanest way to address this problem.
